Title: Wisdom Traits
Description: Recognize the limits of your knowledge, acknowledge uncertainty and change, attention to context and the bigger picture, integrate different perspectives of a situation,... balance intrapersonal (self), interpersonal (others), and institutional (society) interests,... and emotional regulation.

Title: Blind Men And An Elephant
Description: Consider multiple perspectives as no single viewpoint captures the whole truth.

Title: Buridan's Ass
Description: Excessive indecision between options risks inaction and missed opportunities.

Title: Willpower Paradox
Description: People may do things better by focusing less directly on doing them.

Title: Inventor's Paradox
Description: Solving general problems can reveal principles to solve specific problems.

Title: Suspension Of Disbelief
Description: Ignoring the impossible aspects of fiction to enjoy it.

Title: Occam's Razor
Description: Explanations that require fewer unjustified assumptions are more likely to be correct.

Title: Hanlon's Razor
Description: Actions that might seem malicious could be the result of stupidity.

Title: Hitchens’s Razor
Description: Claims asserted without evidence can be dismissed without evidence.

Title: Popper’s Falsifiability Criterion
Description: Scientific theories must be testable and falsifiable.

Title: Sagan Standard
Description: Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence.

Title: Memento Mori
Description: Remember that your time is finite and you will inevitably die.

Title: Chesterton's Fence
Description: Don’t change something until you understand why it exists.

Title: Swiss Cheese Model
Description: No safeguard is perfect so use multiple to prevent a single point of failure.

Title: Bus Factor
Description: The risk of losing critical knowledge if key team members leave or die.

Title: Idea Metaphors
Description: Location (movement), object (manipulated), and food (consumed)

Title: Rose, Thorn, And Bud
Description: "What is going well?, "What is not working?", and "What could we try?”

Title: XY Problem
Description: Ensure the root cause of a problem is correctly identified before finding a solution.

Title: Yak Shaving
Description: Don’t get sidetracked by small trivial tasks that detract from the main goal.

Title: Decision Heuristics
Description: Take-the-first, take-the-best, hiatus, default, priority, recognition, fluency, tradeoff, and trial-and-error

Title: Don’t Ask The Barber For A Haircut
Description: Those who benefit from your decision are incentivized to promote it.

Title: Dunning–Kruger Effect
Description: Unskilled people often overestimate their abilities and skilled people often underestimate their abilities.

Title: Goodhart's Law
Description: When a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure.

Title: Brooks's Law
Description: Adding manpower to a late software project makes it later.

Title: Hofstadter's Law
Description: Tasks always take longer than you expect.

Title: Gall's Law
Description: Functioning complex systems evolve from functioning simple systems.

Title: Pareto Principle
Description: 80% of consequences stem from 20% of the causes.

Title: Tesler's Law
Description: Every software application has an inherent amount of complexity that cannot be removed or hidden.

Title: Front Page Test
Description: How would you feel if everyone knew about your actions?

Title: Everybody, Somebody, Anybody, And Nobody
Description: Take responsibility and don't assume others will do what you won’t.

Title: Relevance Question
Description: "Will this matter a year from now?”

Title: Productivity Questions
Description: “What am I doing now?”, “Is it getting me anywhere?", and “What else could I be doing instead?”

Title: Improve Metacognition
Description: Self-questioning,... think aloud,... and make graphic representations of thoughts and knowledge.

Title: Time Wasters
Description: Lack of priorities, waiting for inspiration, doing everything yourself, worrying what people will say, not living your life, fearing failure, complaining, unfinished tasks, pleasing everybody, comparing yourself to others, repeating mistakes, and perfectionism
